keyTakeAways: The NBA is experiencing a global surge in international talent, with 125 international players on opening night rosters in 2024-25.
Amari Williams, a center from Great Britain, was drafted by the Boston Celtics in the 2025 NBA Draft, becoming the sixth British player drafted in the past 25 years.
Williams grew up in Nottingham, England, and trained in rural agricultural boarding colleges due to limited access to basketball facilities.
The UK has over 1.5 million weekly basketball players and a 24% rise in NBA fandom since 2022, indicating strong grassroots popularity.
Despite popularity, the lack of structured development pathways and mentorship leads to few British players advancing to the NBA.
Tosan Evbuomwan, a British player born in Newcastle, overcame limited access and no formal training to reach the NBA via Princeton University and multiple two-way contracts.
The British Basketball Federation (BBF) was suspended by FIBA in October 2025 due to governance and regulatory non-compliance, disrupting national competition.
An ongoing dispute between the BBF and investor groups is heading to the UK High Court, with an initial hearing scheduled for July 2026.
The UK government and NBA have jointly pledged £10 million to expand basketball at the grassroots level from 2026 to 2028, promoting community inclusion and youth development.
Amari Williams and Tosan Evbuomwan cite each other as role models, showing the importance of mentorship in British basketball development.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The NBA is experiencing a global surge in international talent, with 125 players from 43 countries on opening night rosters in 2024-25. Amid this growth, British basketball remains underrepresented in the NBA despite over 1.5 million weekly players and a 24% rise in NBA fandom. Amari Williams, a center from Nottingham, became the sixth British player drafted into the NBA in the last 25 years after a journey marked by limited training facilities and rural upbringing. Similarly, Tosan Evbuomwan, from Newcastle, overcame a lack of formal structure to reach the NBA through college basketball at Princeton. However, systemic issues plague British basketball, including the suspension of the British Basketball Federation (BBF) by FIBA in October 2025 due to governance failures and an ongoing dispute with investors. Despite these challenges, a joint £10 million investment from the UK government and the NBA (2026–2028) aims to expand grassroots access, with Williams and Evbuomwan cited as inspirational figures for future British players.
title: The NBA is at its international peak, but British players are still struggling to break through
